description: Concerning sexually violent predators' ineligibility to earn supervision compliance credit.

original.text:
H-0194.1
HOUSE BILL 1091
State of Washington
69th Legislature
2025 Regular Session
ByRepresentatives Couture, Leavitt, Schmidt, Low, Jacobsen, Bronoske, Penner, and Caldier
Prefiled 12/18/24.Read first time 01/13/25.Referred to Committee on Community Safety.
AN ACT Relating to sexually violent predators' ineligibility to earn supervision compliance credit; and amending RCW 9.94A.717.
BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF WASHINGTON:
Sec. 1. RCW 9.94A.717 and 2020 c 275 s 2 are each amended to read as follows:
(1) If an offender sentenced under this chapter or chapter 9.94B RCW is supervised by the department, the offender may earn supervision compliance credit in accordance with procedures that are developed and adopted by the department.
(a) The supervision compliance credit shall be awarded to offenders who are in compliance with supervision terms and are making progress towards the goals of their individualized supervision case plan, including: Participation in specific targeted interventions, risk-related programming, or treatment; or completing steps towards specific targeted goals that enhance protective factors and stability, as determined by the department.
(b) For each month in compliance with community custody conditions in accordance with (a) of this subsection, an offender may earn supervision compliance credit of ten days.
(c) Supervision compliance credit is accrued monthly and time shall not be applied to an offender's term of supervision prior to the earning of the time.
(2) An offender is not eligible to earn supervision compliance credit if he or she:
(a) Was sentenced under RCW 9.94A.507 or 10.95.030;
(b) Was sentenced under RCW 9.94A.650, 9.94A.655, 9.94A.660, or 9.94A.670;
(c) Is subject to supervision pursuant to RCW 9.94A.745;
(d) Has an indeterminate sentence and is subject to parole pursuant to RCW 9.95.017; or
(e) Is serving community custody pursuant to early release under RCW 9.94A.730.
(3) An offender is not eligible to earn supervision compliance credit on any cause being served concurrently with a less restrictive alternative subject to supervision pursuant to RCW 71.09.092.
--- END ---

summary.text:
Purpose

The purpose of House Bill 1091 is to amend existing laws regarding sexually violent predators and their ability to earn supervision compliance credit. The bill proposes to make certain offenders ineligible for such credits, which can help reduce their supervision period based on compliance with set conditions. Key changes include the clarification of specific offenses and conditions under which offenders will not qualify for earning compliance credits, aiming to enhance public safety by maintaining stricter oversight of these individuals.

Key Provisions

Changes to Eligibility for Supervision Compliance Credit

  • Offenders are no longer eligible to earn supervision compliance credit if they:
    • Were sentenced under specific regulations (RCW 9.94A.507 or 10.95.030).
    • Were sentenced under additional specified regulations (RCW 9.94A.650, 9.94A.655, 9.94A.660, or 9.94A.670).
    • Are subject to supervision under RCW 9.94A.745.
    • Have an indeterminate sentence and are eligible for parole (RCW 9.95.017).
    • Are serving community custody under early release (RCW 9.94A.730).
  • Offenders are also ineligible for compliance credit for any time served concurrently with less restrictive alternatives subject to supervision (RCW 71.09.092).

This adjustment emphasizes the state's focus on accountability for sexually violent predators and aims to reinforce supervision procedures.
